Cloze

fields: Cells can communicate with one another in different ways. What are the three main ways?
Endocrine, paracrine, autocrine
{{c1::Paracrine}} and {{c1::autocrine}} signals have to be limited in their {{c2::diffusion}} to ensure that they are delivered to their proper target.

Mechanisms by which paracrine and autocrine signals have to be limited in their diffusion.
-Rapid {{c1::endocytosis}} of signal by neighboring cells.
-Desctruction by {{c1::extracellular}} enzymes
-Immobilization by {{c1::extracellular matrix}}.
Small molecules that serve as signaling molecules
Amino acids, gases (NO), ions (Ca2+), nucleotides
Receptors can be {{c1::ion channels}} and ligand binding causes a change in membrane potential. In this case, the only machinery needed for signal transcution is the {{c1::receptor}}.
Usually {{c1::ligand}} binding to receptor causes the receptor to associate with an {{c2::effector}} molecule to initiate a cellular response.
T/F Cells only respond to signals for which they have receptors or signaling components.
T
What are the five types of receptors

ligand-gated ion receptors
G protein coupled receptors
Catalytic receptors
Nuclear receptors.
{{c2::ligand-gated}} ion channel receptors are {{c1::integral}} membrane proteins
{{c1::Ligand-gated}} ion channel receptors are also hybrid {{c2::receptors/channels}} that are involved in {{c3::signaling}} between electrically excitable cells
{{c1::ligand gated}} ion channels transduce a {{c2::chemical}} signal into an {{c2::electrical}} signal
{{c1::Ligand gated}} ion channels are a {{c2::multisubunit}} membrane spanning receptors
{{c1::Signaling molecules}} control the openining and closing of ion channels by {{c2::binding}} to a site on the receptor
{{c2::Ionotropic receptors}} is another name for a {{c1::ligand gated ion channel}}
Ionotropic receptors for {{c2::acetylcholine}}, {{c2::serotonin}}, and {{c2::GABA}} are good examples of ligand gated ion channels
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} are integral plasma membrane proteins
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} work through an {{c2::intermediary}} to activate/inactivate a separate membrane associated enzyme or channel
The intermediary in a G protein-coupled receptors is {{c1::GTP}}
G protein-coupled receptors constitue the largest family of receptors on the {{c1::cell surface}}
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} mediate a cellular response to a diverse array of {{c2::signaling}} molecules (hormones, neurotransmitters, odorants etc)
Despite the {{c1::chemical}} diversity of their ligands, most {{c2::receptors}} have a similar structure
{{c1::G protein-coupled receptors}} have {{c2::seven}} membrane-spanning alpha-helical segments
A {{c1::ligand binds}} onto G protein-coupled receptors on the extracellular {{c2::N terminus}} that is glycosylated
a {{c2::G protein-coupled receptor}} has a large cytoplasmic loope that has {{c3::hydrophilic}} amino acids between helices {{c1::5 and 6}}
G proteins are a member of the {{c1::GTP-binding protein}} family
G proteins are {{c1::heterotrimers}} that exist in many combinations of different {{c2::alpha, beta, & gamma}} subunits

The GTP-binding protein family includes:
1) {{c2::heterotrimeric}} G proteins that bind to {{c3::G-protein}} coupled receptors
2) small GTP-binding proteins, such as {{c1::RAS}}
Heterotrimeric and small G proteins can {{c1::hydrolyze}} {{c2::GTP}}
When heterotrimeric and small G proteins are hydrolyzed with GTP, they can switch between an {{c2::active}} {{c1::GTP-bound}} state and an {{c2::inactive}} {{c1::GDP-bound}} state
Heterotrimeric G proteins are composed of three subunits: {{c1::alpha, beta, and gamma}}
The {{c1::alpha}} subunit of heterotrimeric G proteins binds and hydrolyzes {{c2::GTP}}
Example is adenyly cyclase

The {{c1::beta/gamma}} complex of heterotrimeric G proteins, anchors the {{c2::trimeric}} complex to the membrane and functions in {{c3::signal transduction::type of transduction}} by interacting with certain effector molecules
G protein activation follows a {{c1::cycle}}

First step of the G protein activation cycle. Describe this step.

Hint: 1) This is in an inactive state. 2) Interaction between GDP and a specific subunit.

In the inactive state, heterotrimeric G-proteins have three subunits: alpha, beta, and gamma.

GDP occupies the guanine nucleotide-binding site of the alpha subunit.

Second step in the G protein activation cycle.
Describe this step.

After the ligand binds, the activated recptor interacts with the G protein to promote a conformational change. 

GDP is exchanged for GTP
Third step of the G protein activation cycle. Describe this step.
GDP-GTP exchange stimulates dissociation of the complex from the recptor
Fourth step of the G protein activation cycle. Describe this step.
Dissociation of the complex results in a disassembly of the trimer into a free alpha subunit and beta/gamma complex

Fifth step of the G protein activation cycle. 
Describe this step.

Free & active GTP-bound alpha subunit can now interact with downstream effectors (adenyly cylcase and phospholipases)

Beta/gamma complex can now activate ion channels or other effectors

Sixth step of the G protein activation cycle. 
Describe this step.

Alpha subunit terminates the signaling events by hydrolyzing GTP to GDP and inorganic phosphate

Results in an inactive alpha-GDP complex that dissociates from downstream effector and reassociates with beta/gamma subunit
{{c1::Second messenger}} systems {{c2::amplify}} signals and {{c3::integrate}} responses among cell type
Cells rapidly {{c1::produce or activate}} the second messenger and then {{c2::inactivates or degrades}} it
The involvement of {{c2::second messengers}} in catalytic cascades provides numerous opportunities to {{c1::amplify}} a signal
{{c1::Amplifying}} a signal usually involves the conversion of an {{c2::inactive}} species into an {{c2::active}} one
What are the six examples of second messengers?

- cAMP
- cGMP
- IP3
- DAG
- Arachidonic acid
- Ca2+
Indirect pathway indirectly activates {{c1::phospholipase A2}}
alpha subunit from the receptor G-protein complex 1 activates not {{c1::phosholipase A2}}, but {{c1::phospholipase C beta}}
T/F Phospholipase A2 is used to cleave arachidonic acid from the molecule it was originally attached to
False, PLA2 only cleaves phospholipids
Is DAG a phospholipid?
No, no phosphate
What enzyme is used to cleave/liberate arachidonic acid?
DAG lipase
The indirect pathway releases AA in a {{c1::stepwise}} manner; first cutting {{c1::IP3}}, leaving DAG, then cutting off AA from the molecule with the enzyme {{c1::DAG lipase}}
Any {{c1::agonist}} that raises [Ca2+] can promote AA {{c1::formation}} because Ca2+ can stimulate some {{c1::cystolic forms of PLA2}}
Any {{c1::signal transduction pathway}} that activates MAP kinase can also enhance {{c1::AA release}} because MAP kinase phosphoryates {{c1::PLA2}}
{{c1::Cyclooxygenases, lipoxygenases, epoxygenases}} mediate the formation of biologially active {{c1::eicosanoids}}
Once AA is released from the membrane, it can {{c1::diffuse}} out of the cell, be {{c1::reincorporated}} into membrane phospholipids, or be {{c1::metabolized}}
{{c1::cyclooxygenases}} catalyze conversion of AA into the {{c1::intermediates prostaglandin G2 (PGG2) and prostaglandin H2 (PGH2)}}
PGH2 is the precursor of the other {{c1::prostaglandins, the prostacyclins and the thromboxanes}}
AA can be metabolized by 3 main enzymes: {{c1::lipoxygenases, COX, epoxygenases}}
NSAID inhibition of cyclooxygenase is a useful tool in the {{c1::treatment of inflammation and fever}}
prostaglandin synthesis has been implicated in the pathophysiological mechanisms of {{c1::cardiovascular disease, cancer, and inflammatory diseases}}
NSAIDs such as a{{c1::spirin, acetaminophen, and ibuprofen}} directly target cyclooxygenase
{{c1::5-lipoxygenase}} initiates the conversion of AA into biologically active {{c1::leuktrienes}}
{{c1::leukotrienes}} participate in allergic and inflammatory responses
The {{c1::epoxygenase}} pathway converts AA into two major products, HETE (hydroxyeicosatetraenoic acid) EET (epoxyeicosatrienoic acid)
epoxygenase and HETE pathways plays a role in {{c1::cell proliferation}} and {{c1::Ca2+ release}}
{{c1::Small GTP-binding proteins}} are involved in a vast number of cellular processes
classic heterotrimeric G proteins that bind to GCPR have what 3 parts
alpha, beta, gamma
small GTP-binding proteins are only what subunit, like what type of enzyme?
Ras
A distinct group of proteins that are {{c1::structurally related to the alpha subunit}} of the heterotrimeric G proteins
divided into 5 groups including the {{c1::Ras, Rho, Rab, Arf, and Ran families}}
these 21-kDa proteins can be {{c1::membrane associated}} (e.g. Ras) or may translocate between the {{c1::membrane and the cytosol (eg Rho) }}
Similar to the alpha subunit of heterotrimeric G proteins, the small GTP-binding proteins switch between an {{c1::inactive GDP-bound form}} and an {{c1::active GTP-bound form}}

catalytic receptors

Integral membrane proteins that are {{c1::enzymes}} or part of an {{c1::enzyme complex}}

Receptors that are catalytic

5 classes

1. {{c1::receptor guanylyl cyclases}}
2. {{c1::receptor serine/threonine kinases}}
3. {{c1::receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs)}}
4. {{c1::tyrosine kinase-associated receptors}}
5. {{c1::receptor tyrosine phosphatases}}
receptor guanylyl cyclases {{c1::catalyze the generation of the cGMP from GTP}}
receptor serine/threonine kinases {{c1::phosphorylate serine or threonine residues}} on cellular proteins
receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) {{c1::phosphorylate tyrosine residues on themselves and other proteins}}
tyrosine kinase - associated receptors interact with {{c1::cystolic (ie non-membrane bound) tyrosine kinases}}
receptor guanylyl cylase are found on the {{c1::cell surface}}
which part of guanylyl cylase has enzymatic function?
cytosolic portion, which catalyzes the formation of cGMP from GTP
receptor tyrosine phosphatases {{c1::cleave phosphate groups}} from {{c1::tyrosine groups}} of cellular proteins
Some of the best characterized examples of a transmembrane protein with guanylyl cyclase activity are the {{c1::receptors for the natriuretic peptides}}
molecules that tend to bind the guanylyl cylase domains (the cytosolic receptor) are {{c1::natriuretic peptide (ANP)}}
natriuretic peptides {{c2::act on vascular smooth muscle to dilate blood vessels}}, enhance {{c3::Na+}} excretion into urine, which is termed {{c1::natriuresis}}
natriuretic peptides (ANP) can lower {{c1::blood pressure}}, and help with {{c1::smooth muscle relaxation}}
receptor guanylyl cyclase are membrane proteins with a {{c1::single membrane spanning segment}}

receptor guanylyl cyclase
the {{c1::extracellular domain}} binds the ligand

receptor guanylyl cyclase

The intracellular domain has {{c1::two consensus catalytic}} domains for guanylyl cyclase activity

receptor guanylyl cyclase
binding of a {{c1::natriuretic}} peptide induces a c{{c1::onformational change}} in the receptor that causes {{c1::receptor dimerization and activation}}

receptor guanylyl cyclase

binding of ligand to receptor causes the conversion of GTP to cGMP and raises {{c1::intracellular levels of cGMP}}

soluble guanylyl cyclase
in contrast to the receptor for ANP, which is a membrane protein with guanylyl cyclase activity, the {{c1::receptor for NO is soluble}} (ie cystolic) guanylyl cyclase

soluble guanylyl cyclase
this soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) is {{c1::totally unrelated}} to the receptor guanylyl cyclase and contains a {{c1::heme moiety that binds NO}}

{{c1::soluble guanylyl cyclase}} 
NO plays an important role in the control of blood flow and blood pressure
T/F soluble guanylyl cyclase is NOT on the membrane
T
Blood vessels are lined with {{c1::endothelial cells}}
NO can be produced inside the {{c1::endothelial cells}} that line BV when arginine gets converted to citrulline by enzyme {{c1::NO synthase}}
NO rapidly {{c1::diffuses}} out of the endothelial cell and crosses the membrane of a {{c1::neighboring smooth muscle cell}}
in {{c2::smooth muscle}}, NO stimulates its "receptor", soluble {{c1::guanylyl cyclase,}} which then converts GTP to cGMP
as a result, [cGMP] may increase {{c1::50}}-fold and relax the {{c1::smooth muscle}}
